title: Days & Time Words
objectives: Name days and simple time markers
Place time expressions naturally in sentences
context: Knowing when something happens is often more important than the full sentence.
Korean time words go before the verb and often before particles like 에 (at).
Combine with present tense to talk about plans, routines, and recent past.

sentences.english: I have a meeting tomorrow morning.

explanation: Time words usually come early: [Time] + [Place] + [Verb]. Example: 내일 회사에서 일해요 (Tomorrow I work at the office).
아침/점심/저녁 can pair with 에 to mean 'in/at': 아침에, 점심에, 저녁에.
언제 is flexible: 언제 만나요? 언제 출발해요?
주말 (weekend) vs 주중 (during the week). Add 이번/다음/지난 before weeks or months: 이번 주, 다음 주.
곧 (soon) and 지금 (now) don't take 에. They act like adverbs right before the verb.
